ground_truth: Sir George is staring out of the window, vexed, bristling but defensive as he picks up one of the papers irritatedly, the London Daily Chronicle; he looks at Sir Edward and sighs heavily. Sir Edward stares back, then drops the paper back on his desk, and Sir George looks from him to Sir Edward, then at the document on the secretary's desk. The secretary turns it slowly so it is facing him, and Sir George looks at it like a snake. The secretary picks up a pen and offers it; after a second, Sir George takes the pen and signs angrily. Meanwhile, Sir Edward is at the liquor cabinet and turns, offering Sir George a whiskey in a finely cut glass of crystal. Gandhi grins, dismissing the formality and again grins at the extravagance, followed by a polite little laugh. Jinnah introduces him, and Gandhi makes the pranam, studying him with interest after that comment, while Azad gives a gentle salaam. Gandhi turns, and he stands, awaiting Gandhi's attention, noting that all the others have been dressed in European clothes, but the handsome Europeanized Nehru now wears an Indian tunic much like the one that Gandhi once wore. For a moment Gandhi studies the costume, then a broad smile; he looks at Gandhi. Again the temper of it produces a little silence. He moves to a servant who stands, holding a large tray with a silver service of tea. Of them all, Nehru's manner is the most naturally patrician, and Jinnah watches him with a somewhat envious awareness of it. His stand has produced a little shock of surprise, and holding his tea, he turns to Gandhi with a little smile, as they all look at him with some surprise. As he speaks, he rises and walks to the servant; they all stare at him, startled by his words and the fervor with which he speaks to them. He holds their gaze, then turns to the immobile servant and with a little smile, takes the tray from him and places it on the table next to him. As it sinks in, Gandhi pours some tea then looks up at them with a pleading warmth -- first to Jinnah, and it impresses each one of them, but for all his impact, they still take the measure of him with caution. Patel is the first to recognize the implications, and the idea has caught hold as Lord Chelmsford turns expectantly. His firmness doesn't restore Kinnoch's normal aplomb, and he holds the telegrams forward, glancing at the general. That takes the wind out of all of them as grimly, Lord Chelmsford looks out across the palace's ordered lawns and gardens. A prison door opens, and Gandhi, in prison clothes, is led along a small corridor to a room where the door is held open by a prison guard.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Sir George is gazing out of the pane, annoyed, bristling but guarded as he lifts one of the journals agitatedly, the London Daily Chronicle; he glances at Sir Edward and exhales deeply. Sir Edward peers back, then lets the journal fall back on his bureau, and Sir George glances from him to Sir Edward, then at the manuscript on the assistant's bureau. The assistant rotates it gradually so it is facing him, and Sir George gazes at it like a serpent. The assistant lifts a quill and extends it; after a moment, Sir George takes the quill and inscribes furiously. Meanwhile, Sir Edward is at the spirits cabinet and rotates, extending Sir George a whiskey in a finely cut chalice of crystal. Gandhi smiles, dismissing the formality and again smiles at the opulence, followed by a courteous little chuckle. Jinnah presents him, and Gandhi makes the pranam, observing him with interest after that remark, while Azad gives a gentle salaam. Gandhi turns, and he stands, awaiting Gandhi's focus, noting that all the others have been clad in European garments, but the handsome Europeanized Nehru now wears an Indian tunic much like the one that Gandhi once donned. For a moment Gandhi observes the attire, then a broad grin; he looks at Gandhi. Again the mood of it induces a little silence. He moves to a servant who stands, holding a large platter with a silver service of tea. Of them all, Nehru's demeanor is the most naturally aristocratic, and Jinnah regards him with a somewhat covetous awareness of it. His stance has induced a little shock of surprise, and holding his tea, he turns to Gandhi with a little grin, as they all gaze at him with some surprise. As he speaks, he rises and walks to the servant; they all gape at him, startled by his words and the passion with which he addresses them. He holds their gaze, then turns to the motionless servant and with a little grin, takes the platter from him and places it on the table next to him. As it registers, Gandhi pours some tea then gazes at them with a pleading warmth -- first to Jinnah, and it impresses each one of them, but for all his influence, they still take the measure of him with wariness. Patel is the first to recognize the ramifications, and the notion has caught hold as Lord Chelmsford turns hopefully. His determination doesn't restore Kinnoch's usual composure, and he holds the telegrams forward, glancing at the general. That takes the wind out of all of them as grimly, Lord Chelmsford gazes out across the palace's arranged lawns and gardens. A prison door opens, and Gandhi, in prison garments, is led along a small corridor to a chamber where the entrance is held open by a prison guard.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Sir George is stared at out of the window, vexed, bristling but defensive as one of the papers is picked up by him irritatedly, the London Daily Chronicle; Sir Edward is looked at by him, and a heavy sigh is heaved. Sir Edward stares back, then the paper is dropped by him back on his desk, and Sir George looks from him to Sir Edward, then at the document on the secretary's desk. The document is turned slowly by the secretary so it is facing him, and it is looked at by Sir George like a snake. A pen is picked up by the secretary and offered; after a second, the pen is taken by Sir George and signed angrily. Meanwhile, Sir Edward is at the liquor cabinet and turns, offering Sir George a whiskey in a finely cut glass of crystal. Gandhi grins, dismissing the formality and again grins at the extravagance, followed by a polite little laugh. Jinnah introduces him, and the pranam is made by Gandhi, who studies him with interest after that comment, while a gentle salaam is given by Azad. Gandhi turns, and he is stood by, awaiting Gandhi's attention, noting that all the others have dressed in European clothes, but the handsome Europeanized Nehru now wears an Indian tunic much like the one once worn by Gandhi. For a moment, the costume is studied by Gandhi, then a broad smile; Gandhi is looked at by him. Again the temper of it produces a little silence. He moves to a servant who stands, holding a large tray with a silver service of tea. Of them all, Nehru's manner is the most naturally patrician, and him, Jinnah watches with a somewhat envious awareness of it. His stand produces a little shock of surprise, and holding his tea, he turns to Gandhi with a little smile, as they all look at him with some surprise. As he rises to speak, he walks to the servant; they all stare at him, startled by his words and the fervor with which he speaks to them. He holds their gaze, then turns to the immobile servant and with a little smile, takes the tray from him and places it on the table next to him. As it sinks in, some tea is poured by Gandhi, who then looks up at them with a pleading warmthâ€”first to Jinnah, and it impresses each one of them, but for all his impact, he is still measured by them with caution. The implications are first recognized by Patel, and the idea has caught hold as Lord Chelmsford turns expectantly. His firmness doesn't restore Kinnoch's normal aplomb, and the telegrams are held forward by him, glancing at the general. That takes the wind out of all of them as grimly, a look across the palace's ordered lawns and gardens is cast by Lord Chelmsford. A prison door opens, and Gandhi, in prison clothes, is led along a small corridor to a room where a prison guard holds the door open.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Sir George, vexed and defensive, picks up the London Daily Chronicle and sighs heavily at Sir Edward. Sir Edward stares and drops the paper back on the desk. The secretary turns a document toward Sir George, who reluctantly takes a pen and signs. Sir Edward offers Sir George whiskey in a crystal glass. Gandhi grins, dismissing the formality and admires the extravagance. Jinnah introduces him, and Gandhi studies Nehru, who now wears an Indian tunic. Gandhi smiles broadly at Nehru, noting the costume, and moves to a servant holding tea. Nehru's patrician manner surprises the group, as he takes tea and engages Gandhi. Gandhi pours tea warmly, impressing them, but they remain cautious. Patel sees the implications, as Lord Chelmsford watches expectantly. Kinnoch struggles with his aplomb as Lord Chelmsford grimly surveys the palace lawns. In prison clothes, Gandhi is led by a guard to a room with an open door.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Sir George, vexed and defensive, picks up the London Daily Chronicle and sighs at Sir Edward, who drops the paper on his desk. Observing Sir Edward and a document turned towards him by the secretary, Sir George signs it angrily after taking a pen. Meanwhile, Sir Edward offers Sir George whiskey in a crystal glass. Gandhi grins at the formality, dismisses it, and makes a pranam after Jinnah's introduction, acknowledging Azad's salaam. Noting the European-dressed others, Gandhi sees Nehru in an Indian tunic similar to his own. Gandhi's attention shifts as Nehru, naturally patrician, surprises everyone by taking a tray from a servant and placing it on the table. Gandhi pours tea, impressing them, especially Patel and Lord Chelmsford. Kinnoch, holding telegrams, falters as Lord Chelmsford grimly gazes across the palace lawns. A prison door opens as Gandhi, in prison clothes, is led to a room by a guard.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Sir George, standing by the window, finds himself lost in thought, his gaze fixed on the scenery outside. His expression is one of clear vexation, as he seems to bristle with an air of defensiveness. With a sense of irritation, he reaches out to grab one of the many newspapers scattered around him. It's none other than the London Daily Chronicle that he picks up, and after giving it a cursory glance, he turns his attention to Sir Edward, accompanied by a deep, heavy sigh that echoes his inner turmoil. Sir Edward returns the gaze with a steady look of his own before casually allowing the paper to slip from his fingers and land back on his desk. Sir George's eyes dart back and forthâ€”from Sir Edward to the pieces of paper strewn across the desk, then to the document lying prominently on the secretary's table. The secretary, noticing his interest, swivels the document towards Sir George, who regards it with suspicion, reminiscent of staring at a coiled snake poised to strike. Slowly, the secretary extends a pen towards Sir George. With a moment's hesitation, Sir George grabs it and, with an air of anger, scribbles his signature across the page.

Meanwhile, Sir Edward steps over to the well-stocked liquor cabinet. He selects a finely cut crystal glass and fills it with whiskey, turning to proffer the glass to Sir George. Somewhere nearby, Gandhi observes the unfolding scene, his face breaking into a grin that dismisses the formality of the situation. The extravagance on display prompts a polite chuckle from him. At this juncture, Jinnah makes an introduction, prompting Gandhi to perform a pranam, a respectful gesture, and then study his counterpart with keen interest following the comment. Azad greets Gandhi with a gentle salaam, and Gandhi, in return, faces him. As he stands there, waiting for Gandhi's attention, Gandhi notes the attire of the others. While everyone else sports European-style clothing, the notably handsome and Europeanized Nehru dons an Indian tunic that bears a striking resemblance to the one Gandhi himself once wore. For a brief moment, Gandhi scrutinizes the outfit, then his face breaks into a broad smile. He shifts his gaze toward Gandhi, and the mood in the room shifts to one of quietude as the intensity of the moment takes hold.

A servant, standing nearby, holds a large tray bearing a silver tea service. Nehru, of all those present, exudes a naturally aristocratic manner, which Jinnah observes with a slightly envious twinge. Nehru's stance evokes a ripple of surprise throughout the group. Holding his tea, Nehru turns toward Gandhi with a soft smile, aware of the surprised expressions directed his way. As he begins to speak, he rises and strides confidently over to the servant. His words and fervent manner astonish the others, leaving them momentarily transfixed. He maintains his gaze on them before shifting his focus to the still servant, offering a friendly smile as he takes the tray from him and places it gently on the table beside him. As the significance of his actions begin to sink in, Gandhi pours himself a cup of tea. His eyes lift with a warm, pleading expressionâ€”his gaze first seeking out Jinnah, impressing those around him. Despite the impact of his presence, the others continue to weigh and measure him with a certain caution. Patel is the first to fully grasp the implications of the situation, and as the concept takes root, Lord Chelmsford turns with an air of expectancy. His firmness does little to restore Kinnoch's usual composure, and Kinnoch extends a handful of telegrams, casting a glance toward the general. The weight of the moment takes them by surprise, as Lord Chelmsford gazes seriously at the meticulously groomed lawns and gardens of the palace. Meanwhile, a prison door creaks open, revealing Gandhi, now clad in the simple garments of a prisoner, being led down a narrow corridor toward a room. A prison guard stands at the ready, holding the door open for him as he is ushered inside.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Sir George, who is standing pensively by the window, finds himself completely absorbed in thought, his unwavering gaze fixed on the scenery sprawling outside. His expression unmistakably reveals a sense of clear vexation, as he seems to bristle with the palpable air of defensiveness. With a mounting sense of irritation, he extends his hand to grab one of the numerous newspapers scattered haphazardly around him. It's none other than the London Daily Chronicle that he ultimately chooses, and after providing it with nothing more than a cursory glance, he redirects his attention to Sir Edward. Accompanying this shift in focus is a deep, heavy sigh that reverberates with echoes of his inner turmoil. Sir Edward, in turn, meets this look with a steady, unwavering gaze of his own before nonchalantly letting the paper slip from his fingers, allowing it to land back on his desk. Sir George's eyes flicker back and forthâ€”darting from Sir Edward to the array of papers scattered across the desk, and then fixating on the document that lies prominently on the secretary's table. The secretary, noticing his heightened interest, deliberately swivels the document around so that it faces Sir George, who regards it with a suspicious gaze, reminiscent of someone staring at a coiled snake poised to strike. With deliberate slowness, the secretary extends a pen towards Sir George. After a brief moment of hesitation, Sir George snatches it and, with an air of anger, hurriedly scribbles his signature across the page.

Meanwhile, Sir Edward casually makes his way over to the well-stocked liquor cabinet in the room. From there, he selects a finely cut crystal glass and proceeds to fill it with whiskey, turning to offer the glass to Sir George. Somewhere nearby, Gandhi observes the unfolding scene, his face breaking into a broad grin that effortlessly dismisses the formality of the situation. The extravagance on display prompts a soft, polite chuckle to escape from him. At this particular juncture, Jinnah steps forward and makes an introduction, prompting Gandhi to perform a pranamâ€”a respectful gestureâ€”and then study his counterpart with keen interest following the comment. Azad greets Gandhi with a gentle salaam, to which Gandhi, in turn, faces him. As he stands patiently waiting for Gandhi's attention, Gandhi takes note of the attire worn by the others. While everyone else is dressed in European-style clothing, the notably handsome and Europeanized Nehru is clad in an Indian tunic that bears a striking resemblance to one that Gandhi himself once wore. For a brief, contemplative moment, Gandhi scrutinizes the outfit, then his face breaks into a warm, broad smile. He shifts his gaze toward Gandhi again, and the overall mood in the room transitions to one of quietude as the intensity of the moment gradually takes hold.

Nearby, a servant stands ready, holding a large tray adorned with a silver tea service. Among all those present, Nehru exudes an effortlessly aristocratic manner, which Jinnah observes with a slightly envious twinge. Nehru's poised stance evokes a ripple of surprise throughout the assembled group. Holding his cup of tea, Nehru turns and directs a soft smile toward Gandhi, acutely aware of the surprised expressions directed at him. As he begins to speak, he rises and strides confidently over to where the servant stands. His words and fervent manner astonish the others, momentarily leaving them in a state of transfixed attention. He maintains his gaze on them before shifting his focus to the still-standing servant, offering a friendly smile as he takes the tray from him and places it gently on the table beside him. As the full significance of his actions begins to sink in, Gandhi pours himself a cup of tea. His eyes lift, radiating a warm, pleading expressionâ€”his gaze seeking out Jinnah first, leaving an impression on those around him. Despite the impact of his presence, the others continue to weigh and measure him with a certain degree of caution. Patel is the first to fully grasp the implications of the situation, and as the concept takes root, Lord Chelmsford turns with an air of expectancy. His firmness does little to restore Kinnoch's usual composure, as Kinnoch extends a handful of telegrams, casting a glance in the direction of the general. The weight of the moment takes them all by surprise, as Lord Chelmsford gazes seriously at the meticulously groomed lawns and gardens of the palace. Meanwhile, a prison door creaks open, revealing Gandhi, now dressed in the simple garments of a prisoner, being led down a narrow corridor toward a room. A prison guard stands at the ready, holding the door open for him as he is ushered inside.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Sir George stands by the window, his gaze fixed outward with a mix of vexation and defensiveness. As frustration bubbles beneath the surface, he reaches out and snatches up the London Daily Chronicle from the desk, his fingers gripping the paper tightly in irritation before he fixes his eyes on Sir Edward, releasing a heavy sigh that conveys his inner tumult. Sir Edward meets his gaze briefly before letting his own paper slip from his grasp back onto the desk, creating a soft rustle. Sir George's eyes flicker between Sir Edward and a document prominently displayed on the secretary's desk. Sensing the urgency, the secretary slowly rotates the document so that it directly faces Sir George, who eyes it warily, as if it were a serpent poised to strike. The secretary then lifts a pen and extends it to Sir George, who hesitates for a moment before snatching the pen and signing his name with clear agitation. Meanwhile, Sir Edward strolls over to the liquor cabinet, turning back to Sir George with an offering of whiskey in a finely cut crystal glass, signaling a silent gesture of conciliation. At this moment, Gandhi enters the scene with a grin, dismissing the stifling formality with his warm expression and punctuating it with a lighthearted chuckle. Jinnah steps forward to introduce Gandhi, who responds with a graceful pranam, his eyes keenly observing after the preceding commentary, while Azad acknowledges Gandhi with a gentle salaam. Gandhi turns his attention to the gathering, noting with interest the attire of the attendees; he observes that, unlike the others clad in European clothing, Nehru now dons an Indian tunic reminiscent of the style Gandhi himself once favored. A fleeting pause ensues as Gandhi examines Nehru's attire, followed by a broad smile directed at Gandhi, creating a momentary silence in the room. Gandhi approaches a servant standing nearby holding a large tray laden with a silver tea service. Of the attendees, Nehru exudes a naturally aristocratic demeanor, which Jinnah observes with a mixture of admiration and envy. Nehru's actions momentarily stun the group as he takes his tea with a composed elegance, turning to Gandhi with a subtle smile that intrigues the assembly. As he speaks, he rises gracefully and walks over to the servant; the room's occupants watch him, captivated by his words and the intensity he brings. Nehru maintains eye contact with the group before turning back to the servant and, with a gentle smile, accepts the tray, placing it carefully on the table beside him. As the significance of the moment sinks in, Gandhi pours himself a cup of tea and casts a warm, imploring glance around the roomâ€”starting with Jinnahâ€”evoking an impression that resonates with each attendee, yet they remain cautiously analytical. Patel is the first to grasp the deeper implications of the situation, as the idea begins to take root in their minds. Lord Chelmsford's attention shifts expectantly toward him, though his resolute demeanor fails to re-establish Kinnoch's usual composure. Holding a stack of telegrams in front of him, Kinnoch glances at the general, effectively silencing the room. With a grim expression, Lord Chelmsford gazes across the meticulously maintained lawns and gardens of the palace. In a stark contrast, a prison door swings open elsewhere, and Gandhi, now clad in prison attire, is escorted down a narrow corridor to a room where a guard stands, holding the door ajar for his entry.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Sir George, feeling vexed and defensive, picks up the London Daily Chronicle and exchanges a heavy sigh with Sir Edward. After glancing between Sir Edward and a document on the secretary's desk, he reluctantly signs it after the secretary presents him with a pen. Sir Edward, meanwhile, offers George a whiskey from the liquor cabinet. As Gandhi enters with a grin, dismissing formality, Jinnah introduces him, prompting Gandhi to greet with a pranam, observing with interest the European-dressed individuals, particularly Nehru in a traditional Indian tunic. Gandhi smiles as Nehru, with a naturally patrician manner, surprises everyone by taking a tea tray from a servant and placing it on the table. Gandhi, pouring tea with a warm plea, impresses the onlookers. Patel perceives the implications, catching Lord Chelmsford's attention, though it rattles Kinnoch's composure as he presents telegrams to the general. Meanwhile, Lord Chelmsford surveys the palace gardens grimly. In another scene, Gandhi, now in prison clothes, is led by a guard through a corridor to a waiting room.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Sir George, a distinguished member of the British aristocracy, is staring out of the window, vexed, bristling but defensive as he picks up one of the papers irritatedly, the London Daily Chronicle, a well-regarded newspaper known for its coverage of international affairs; he looks at Sir Edward and sighs heavily. Sir Edward, an influential political figure, stares back, then drops the paper back on his ornate mahogany desk, and Sir George looks from him to Sir Edward, then at the document on the secretary's desk, which pertains to a crucial policy change regarding colonial governance. The secretary, who has served in various diplomatic roles, turns it slowly so it is facing him, and Sir George looks at it like a snake, recognizing its potential impact on relations with India. The secretary picks up a pen and offers it; after a second, Sir George takes the pen and signs angrily, his decision weighed by international pressure. Meanwhile, Sir Edward is at the liquor cabinet, an elaborate piece of furniture imported from Italy, and turns, offering Sir George a whiskey in a finely cut glass of crystal, a symbol of British opulence. Gandhi grins, dismissing the formality and again grins at the extravagance, followed by a polite little laugh that acknowledges the cultural contrast. Jinnah, a prominent leader in the Indian independence movement, introduces him, and Gandhi makes the pranam, an Indian gesture of respect, studying him with interest after that comment, while Azad, another key figure in the movement, gives a gentle salaam, reflecting his Muslim heritage. Gandhi turns, and he stands, awaiting Gandhi's attention, noting that all the others have been dressed in European clothes, but the handsome Europeanized Nehru now wears an Indian tunic much like the one that Gandhi once wore, symbolizing a return to native roots. For a moment Gandhi studies the costume, then a broad smile; he looks at Gandhi. Again the temper of it produces a little silence. He moves to a servant who stands, holding a large tray with a silver service of tea, a ritual underscoring British colonial influence. Of them all, Nehru's manner is the most naturally patrician, and Jinnah watches him with a somewhat envious awareness of it. His stand has produced a little shock of surprise, and holding his tea, he turns to Gandhi with a little smile, as they all look at him with some surprise. As he speaks, he rises and walks to the servant; they all stare at him, startled by his words and the fervor with which he speaks to them, echoing sentiments of self-governance. He holds their gaze, then turns to the immobile servant and with a little smile, takes the tray from him and places it on the table next to him. As it sinks in, Gandhi pours some tea, a symbolic act of hospitality and equality, then looks up at them with a pleading warmth -- first to Jinnah, and it impresses each one of them, but for all his impact, they still take the measure of him with caution. Patel, another leader in India's struggle for independence, is the first to recognize the implications, and the idea has caught hold as Lord Chelmsford, the British Viceroy of India, turns expectantly. His firmness doesn't restore Kinnoch's normal aplomb, and he holds the telegrams forward, glancing at the general, who manages military operations in British India. That takes the wind out of all of them as grimly, Lord Chelmsford looks out across the palace's ordered lawns and gardens, testimony to colonial grandeur. A prison door opens, and Gandhi, in prison clothes, is led along a small corridor to a room where the door is held open by a prison guard, reflecting the British authorities' frequent imprisonment of independence leaders.

test_cases.description: Sir George is staring out of the window vexed bristling but defensive as he picks up one of the papers irritatedly the London Daily Chronicle. he looks at Sir Edward and sighs heavily. Sir Edward stares back then drops the paper back on his desk and Sir George looks from him to Sir Edward then at the document on the secretary's desk. The secretary turns it slowly so it is facing him and Sir George looks at it like a snake. The secretary picks up a pen and offers it. after a second. Sir George takes the pen and signs angrily. Meanwhile Sir Edward is at the liquor cabinet and turns offering Sir George a whiskey in a finely cut glass of crystal. Gandhi grins dismissing the formality and again grins at the extravagance followed by a polite little laugh. Jinnah introduces him and Gandhi makes the pranam studying him with interest. after that comment while Azad gives a gentle salaam. Gandhi turns and he stands awaiting Gandhi's attention noting that all the others have been dressed in European clothes but the handsome Europeanized Nehru now wears an Indian tunic much like the one that Gandhi once wore. For a moment Gandhi studies the costume then a broad smile he looks at Gandhi. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the cityâ€™s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles natureâ€™s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby cafÃ©, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

As Nehru approaches a servant with a tea tray, his unexpected action surprises everyone. Gandhi pours tea, impressing them with warmth, yet they remain cautious. Patel realizes the implications of the situation as Lord Chelmsford observes the palace grounds thoughtfully. Meanwhile, Gandhi, now in prison clothes, is led by a guard to a room.

secretary's desk he looks at Sir Edward and sighs heavily Sir George is staring out of the window vexed bristling but defensive as he picks up one of the papers irritatedly the London Daily Chronicle

test_cases.name: Jumble Segments Order
test_cases.description: His stand has produced a little shock of surprise and holding his tea For a moment Gandhi studies the costume then a broad smile he looks at Gandhi Jinnah introduces him and Gandhi makes the pranam studying him with interest A prison door opens and Gandhi in prison clothes is led along a small corridor to a room where the door is held open by a prison guard they all stare at him startled by his words and the fervor with which he speaks to them Sir George takes the pen and signs angrily after a second after that comment while Azad gives a gentle salaam Of them all Nehru's manner is the most naturally patrician and Jinnah watches him with a somewhat envious awareness of it Patel is the first to recognize the implications and the idea has caught hold as Lord Chelmsford turns expectantly Gandhi turns and he stands awaiting Gandhi's attention noting that all the others have been dressed in European clothes but the handsome Europeanized Nehru now wears an Indian tunic much like the one that Gandhi once wore As he speaks he rises and walks to the servant he looks at Sir Edward and sighs heavily He moves to a servant who stands holding a large tray with a silver service of tea His firmness does not restore Kinnoch's normal aplomb and he holds the telegrams forward glancing at the general That takes the wind out of all of them as grimly Again the temper of it produces a little silence Sir Edward stares back then drops the paper back on his desk and Sir George looks from him to Sir Edward then at the document on the secretary's desk he turns to Gandhi with a little smile as they all look at him with some surprise Lord Chelmsford looks out across the palace's ordered lawns and gardens The secretary picks up a pen and offers it As it sinks in Gandhi pours some tea then looks up at them with a pleading warmth  first to Jinnah and it impresses each one of them but for all his impact they still take the measure of him with caution Meanwhile Sir Edward is at the liquor cabinet and turns offering Sir George a whiskey in a finely cut glass of crystal Gandhi grins dismissing the formality and again grins at the extravagance followed by a polite little laugh Sir George is staring out of the window vexed bristling but defensive as he picks up one of the papers irritatedly the London Daily Chronicle The secretary turns it slowly so it is facing him and Sir George looks at it like a snake He holds their gaze then turns to the immobile servant and with a little smile takes the tray from him and places it on the table next to him
